Title: In a finite field product of non-square elements is a square
Content: I came across one problem in a finite field as follows: Let $F$ be a finite field. Show that if $a, b\in F$ both are non-squares, then $ab$ is a square. I wanted to prove it by using the idea of Biquadratic field extension. But there is no biquadratic extension over finite fields. Please, any hints for proving above fact? Thanks.
AcceptedAnswer: If the characteristic of $F$ is $2$, then $x\mapsto x^2$ is an automorphism of $F$ and therefore every element is a square. So we can assume the characteristic is an odd prime. Consider the multiplicative group $F^*$ of nonzero elements; the map $x\mapsto x^2$ is a group endomorphism of $F^*$ with kernel $\{1,-1\}$. Therefore the image $H$ of this map is a subgroup satisfying $|H|=|F^*|/2$; this amounts to saying that $H$, which is the set of all squares in $F^*$, has index $2$. Therefore $F^*/H$ is a two-element group and the statement follows.
